Legal_Issue: Was the immigration officer's refusal of Westmore's H&C application reasonable?
Evidence_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence of hardship but ignored sworn statements about lack of UK support
Credibility_Factor: Sworn statements about lack of support in the UK were provided
Legal_Rule: Under s. 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, the Minister may grant permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds if justified
Procedural_Issue: Matter returned for reconsideration by a different officer due to unreasonable decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship upon removal to the UK, ties to Canada, lack of support in home country
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; decision quashed due to unreasonableness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Failure to consider key evidence rendered the process unfair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Ties to Canada, sworn statements regarding lack of support in the UK
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to the reasonableness of the refusal of H&C application
Court_Result: Decision quashed; ordered reconsideration by a different officer
Legal_Rule_Source: s. 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Type: Evidence of familial and community ties in Canada
Outcome: Application denied initially; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Provision: s. 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Rule: s. 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
